page.title: 02INTRODUCTION (P2)
page.content: The name Cheesden is believed to have been derived from 'kis' which is pronounced locally as 'chis' and 'den' meaning a deep narrow wooded vale of a rivulet.'kis' means gravel. The valley is quite remote from the nearest town BURY. The surroundings are quite desolate. The only commercial premises in the area are 2 public houses and a mobile shop. The New Inn has quite a good trade but it relies on good weather to attract people from outside the area. The area used to be a thriving community in the early 1900's. The mills and the houses of the mill workers are still there today but they are unoccupied and in ruins.
